repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

did.abstract: Kenneth Arrow (1921-2017) was a Nobel Prize-winning economist and a professor of economics at Stanford University and Harvard University. This collection consists of his correspondence, research, writings, and other materials documenting his political and personal interests, as well as his collaborations and professional affiliations across the fields of economics, mathematics, public policy, and international relations.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: The collection's correspondence is restricted for ten years following the date of its creation. Contact Research Services to request permission to view recent correspondence. This restriction expires in full by 2027.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: Copyright interests in the papers of Kenneth J. Arrow have not been transferred to Duke University. For further information, see the section on copyright in the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The papers of Kenneth J. Arrow were donated to the Duke University David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library beginning in 1978.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed by: Jonathan Cogliano, Hugo Chu, Matthew Farrell, and Meghan Lyon

B.S., Mathematics, City College of New York
M.A., Mathematics, Columbia University
Weather Officer, US Army Air Corps (ret. Captain)
Married Selma Schweitzer
Research Associate, Cowles Commission for Research in Economics
Assistant Professor of Economics, University of Chicago
Consultant, the RAND Corporation
Acting Assistant Professor, Associate Professor, and Professor of Economics and Statistics, Stanford University
Ph.D., Economics, Columbia University
Publication: Social Choice and Individual Values
Publication (with G. Debreu): Existence of Equilibrium for a Competitive Economy,Econometrica, vol. 22, pp. 265-290.
Awarded John Bates Clark Medal by the American Economics Association (AEA)
Economist, President's Council of Economic Advisers
Professor of Economics, Harvard University
Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences
President, American Economics Association (AEA)
Professor of Economics and Operations Research, Stanford University
President, International Economic Association (IEA)
Died in Palo Alto, California

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: The Kenneth Arrow Papers document his career as an economist, professor, and Nobel Laureate. The collection provides an overview of his many professional activities, along with his research, writings, and collected notes regarding topics such as microeconomics, contingent valuation, social choice theory, general equilibrium analysis, the economics of information, climate change, and endogenous-growth theories. The collection also documents his collaboration and communications with prominent economists such as Robert Aumann, Gerard Debreu, Frank Hahn, John Harsanyi, Leonid Hurwicz, Harold Hotelling, Tjalling Koopmans, Alain Lewis, Lionel McKenzie, Roy Radner, Martin Shubik, Herbert Simon, Robert Solow, and many others.

Along with his own scholarship and writings, the collection documents Arrow's role as an expert witness during various legal cases involving anti-trust lawsuits, international trade, and public utilities; his professional consulting work for different groups and organizations; his political activism supporting different human rights organizations, including his involvement in agencies promoting peace in the Middle East, environmental regulation, arms reduction, and nuclear testing bans; his itineraries, lectures, and public engagements; administrative activities for various professional associations and conferences, including his leadership roles in the American Economic Association, the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, the Beijer Institute, the Econometric Society, the International Economic Association, the Office of Naval Research, the Institute of Medicine, the National Academy of Science, the National Bureau of Economic Research, and many more; and his departmental roles, committee work, and teaching contributions in the Economics Departments of Stanford University, Harvard University, and the Santa Fe Institute. The collection also contains personal artifacts and documents from Arrow's childhood and early education; awards and honorary degrees, including the Clark Medal, the National Medal of Science, and materials from the Nobel Prize ceremony; assorted books from his personal library; various foreign editions of his published works, in multiple languages; and born-digital records with his email and other working documents.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Electronic records in this collection have been migrated to a library server and digital use copies can only be accessed onsite in the Rubenstein Library Reading Room.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains Arrow's files on various individuals. While the series is characterized mostly by correspondence, some files are primarily correspondence with the person, while others are primarily correspondence about the person. This series also includes Arrow's correspondence with various publishers and organizations. Correspondents of note include Robert Aumann, Gerard Debreu, Milton Friedman, Frank Hahn, John Harsanyi, Leonid Hurwicz, Harold Hotelling, Tjalling Koopmans, Alain Lewis, Lionel McKenzie, Paul Samuelson, and Robert Solow.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Correspondence files are restricted for 10 years following their date of creation. Contact Research Services to request access from Arrow's family. The series will open in full by 2027.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains email messages from Arrow's email inbox. Messages between 1999 and 2009 were exported from the Eudora email client, while messages 2009-2017 were exported from Apple Mail. Messages are organized annually, and further divided into files for Arrow's incoming and outgoing correspondence.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Messages are accessible in their current format, but may benefit from additional treatment as email processing tools reach greater levels of stability.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series includes files on Arrow's various professional activities. These include: conference and workshop presentations; public lectures; files related to service with professional organizations and research institutes and organizations; files from advising on award committees and journal editorial boards; expert witness testimony; and files documenting Arrow's political activities.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Electronic records in this series have been migrated to a library server and digital use copies can only be accessed onsite in the Rubenstein Library Reading Room.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes Arrow's conference and public lecture presentations and administrative work for various committees and institutions, as well as his work as a paid consultant on several projects. The latter includes three extended projects, one on economic growth and policy for the Canadian Institute for Advanced Research, one on climate change for the National Academy of Sciences and one on contingent valuation (the use of surveys to value public goods) for the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Association. The former includes work for the American Economic Association, International Economic Association, National Bureau of Economic Research, as well as for the City College of New York, the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, RAND, Beijer, the National Science Foundation, the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, the Nobel nomination committee, and numerous other organizations.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Electronic records in this sub-series have been migrated to a library server and digital use copies can only be accessed onsite in the Rubenstein Library Reading Room.

scopecontent.p: Includes Arrow's notes and correspondence for research projects, notes from classes taken, and academic writings by others. Research notes include files on Arrow's collaboration with Frank Hahn, the uniqueness of equilibrium, production functions, and uncertainty, among other topics and files of hand-written notes. Arrow's class notes contain materials from courses taken with Harold Hotelling.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Electronic records in this sub-series have been migrated to a library server and digital use copies can only be accessed onsite in the Rubenstein Library Reading Room.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains copies, reprints, drafts, notes, and other documents associated with Arrow's published works. These include: reprints and copies of published journal articles and book chapters; copies of his books, including translated versions; contributions to festschrfit volumes; and documents from his referee activity for academic journals and publishers.
